author: dvdobrovolskiy
body:
Sorry for dump question but why Get-ChildItem ignores variables?

$name = Read-Host "Enter path"
#$folder = Get-ChildItem -Path $name -force -Recurse
#$folder = Get-ChildItem $name -force -Recurse $name
#$folder = Get-ChildItem -force -Recurse "$name "
#any of 3 lines above  Get-ChildItem try to get current folder instead of $name

comments.author: RichardSiddaway
comments.body:
What are you entering for the path?

I tried 


PS>  $name = Read-Host "Enter path"
Enter path: c:\test
PS>  Get-ChildItem -Path $name

on PowerShell 6.1, 6.2 preview 1 and Windows PowerShell v5.1.  
In all cases I got a listing for  Directory: C:\test  as requested

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
Am I reading correctly? You're asking for a *file* name, not a folder? `Get-Item` is the command you need to use there.

I think there might be an existing issue on the behaviour of `Get-ChildItem` when a file path is supplied.

comments.author: dvdobrovolskiy
comments.body:
I need both. I changing dates on files and folders

$folder = Get-ChildItem  -force -Recurse f:\starting folder

{
     $object.LastWriteTime=("26 December 2012 12:05:00")
	 $object.LastAccessTime=("26 December 2012 12:05:00")

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
I'm pretty sure you can't *set* the dates in this fashion, as far as I'm aware. Those properties are, I believe, read-only.

If you can post your full script (with any sensitive data removed), including the path you're entering for Get-ChildItem, I can attempt to isolate the exact problem for you. :)
